subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Duplication smells.  With practice, and a low tolerance for duplicated code, one can develop a keen eye for duplication. Tests will only tell you when
messageBody:
Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

> > I should have qualified that further to be writing tests first _and_ removing
> > all duplication.
>
> How do you know that you removed all duplication? Do you have some
> tests that can prove it?
>

Duplication smells. With practice, and a low tolerance for duplicated code, one
can develop a keen eye for duplication.

Tests will only tell you when you've removed too much code.


>
> I agree that when you :
> - start a brand new project
> - don't have any buggy untested legacy code
> - strictly use test-first for every functionality
> - don't make any mistake in code you think can't break
> - perfectly master refactoring
> - each member of your team share the same level of competence and dedication
>
> you can test all paths of your application. I have two remarks:
> 1) so many Ifs leave plenty of room for mistakes

Yes. It's an iterative process made economical with tests.


>
> 2) having tests for a path does not guarantee that the path will not
> have bugs. (100% code coverage != 100% bug free)
>

As far as I know, there was no claim as to how coverage might relate to defect
density.

The OP asked how to test multiple paths. If you only write new code when a test is
failing, and you work in tiny steps, then each new path is tested when and if it's
needed to make a test pass.

Mike
